description: Here are 10 ways to celebrate the Labor Day weekend in the New York metropolitan region. (An introduction appears on page C1.)

title: Backed by Panama Leader, U.S. Readies Camps
description: As American troops based here prepared for an influx of Cuban refugees, a former supporter of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega who now says he wants friendly relations with Washington was sworn in today as President.

title: Agreement To Cut Costs At T.W.A.
description: Trans World Airlines said yesterday that it had agreed with two of its big unions, the pilots and machinists, on changes in work rules that would enable the carrier to cut costs and help it save money for the lean winter months.

title: Stocks Down For 2d Day; Dow Off 11.98
description: For the second consecutive day, the stock market pulled back from recent gains and closed down on leading indexes -- especially the Nasdaq composite index, which has a large number of high-technology stocks that were hurt by a troubled outlook for the computer business. Bond prices were steady, and the dollar fell.

title: Funds for M.T.A. Logo Should Go for Services
description: To the Editor:

title: Selig May Take a Part In Strike Talks
description: Bud Selig, baseball's acting commissioner, hinted yesterday that he may soon directly enter the negotiations with the players in an effort to end the three-week-old strike.

About Real Estate;
A Pennsylvania Project for Residents 75 and Older
description: A project in the planning stage here is an example of the new alternatives in housing for people 75 and older.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League CHICAGO WHITE SOX -- Extended working agreements with Nashville of the American Association; Birmingham of the Southern League; Prince William of the Carolina League; and South Bend of the Midwest League through 1996. Agreed to a working agreement with Bristol, Va., of the Appalachian League on a two-year contract to compete in the three-month Advanced Rookie League, beginning in June 1995.

description: Here is a sampling of activities planned in the New York metropolitan region for the Labor Day weekend: NEW YORK CITY

title: Police Say Murder Suspect Thinks TV Networks Spied on Him
description: The North Carolina man who shot and killed an NBC stagehand with an assault rifle on a crowded sidewalk in Rockefeller Center on Wednesday told investigators that he had come to New York to wreak vengeance on the major television networks for what he called decades of spying and persecution, from taps on his telephones to zappings by mysterious rays.

description: Here are 10 ways to celebrate the Labor Day weekend in the New York metropolitan region. (An introduction appears on page C1.)

title: Corrections
description: An item in SportsPeople yesterday about the dismissal of assault charges against Derrick Coleman of the New Jersey Nets referred incorrectly to the ownership of Rebar, the Manhattan bar outside which the incident occurred. Coleman's teammate, Jayson Williams, is not a co-owner.

title: P.B.A. Endorses Cuomo
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo came to this Catskill resort community today to accept the endorsement of the New York City Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, the state's largest law-enforcement union, at its annual convention.

title: COMPANY NEWS: The Snack-Food Frontier; Chinese to Get a Taste Of Cheese-Less Cheetos
description: At last, Cheetos, the snack, has come to China, the country. The catch? They don't taste like Cheetos.

title: Avis to Install Hand Controls in More Cars
description: Avis, the nation's second-largest automobile rental company, has agreed to install more hand controls for the disabled in its cars, the Justice Department announced today.

title: Old Miser Bringing Up the Cute Girl Is (a) Marner (b) Martin?
description: It's safe to surmise that nobody but Steve Martin thinks Mr. Martin needed to appear in a lighthearted, contemporary screen version of "Silas Marner," casting himself in the role of George Eliot's lonely miser. But Mr. Martin was doubtless searching for another "Roxanne" and a role with a poignancy to match Cyrano's. So he has adapted this tale in contemporary terms, to the point where a horse in the 1861 version is now a Mercedes-Benz.

title: A Forum For 60's-Style Jamming
description: When the Lollapalooza Festival was here at Jones Beach last month, seven bands played on the festival's main stage during an afternoon and evening of alternative rock. But the seven bands that performed with the third annual Horde tour this afternoon and evening needed two stages to fit all their music into a day.

title: Plop, Plop, Fizz, Fizz: Pierce Eats, Then Wins
description: Mary Pierce, who needed to munch a bunch of Maalox to settle an untimely, unruly stomach at match time, had never played last night's opponent, Katarina Studenikova, had never seen her before. And somewhere in the middle of their second round match on the Stadium Court of the United States Open, the fourth-seeded Pierce began to wonder if she perhaps should have paid more attention to the tall, blonde Slovakian with a full-blown forehand that mirrors her own.

title: Holtz Chooses Powlus
description: Notre Dame Coach LOU HOLTZ ended a weeklong waiting game, and perhaps a calculated diversion last night, when he said that sophomore RON POWLUS would start at quarterback in the season opener against Northwestern at Soldier Field in Chicago tomorrow night. "Powlus will start," Holtz said after the team's last practice session. "I also want him to finish."

title: Arizona Iced Tea Maker Seeks Agency
description: Ferolito Vultaggio & Sons said yesterday that it had contacted eight shops about becoming the first agency to handle the account of its Arizona line of iced teas and other beverages.

description: To the Editor:

title: Margaret O. Strahl, Psychiatrist, 77, Dies
description: Dr. Margaret Olds Strahl, a retired New York psychiatrist and analyst known for her research on the clinical treatment of schizophrenia, died on Monday at the William Hill Health Care Center in Easton, Md. She was 77.

title: With Church Preaching in Vain, Brazilians Embrace Birth Control
description: At a health clinic for working-class women here, the gynecologist initially thought the question was a joke. How often do women make religious objections when birth control techniques are discussed?

title: A Mixed August for Retailers
description: The nation's leading retailers reported mixed results for August yesterday, as consumers continued to demonstrate a penchant for bargain-based shopping.

title: ORACLE TO BUY DATA-BASE UNIT FROM DIGITAL
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its data-base software unit to the Oracle Corporation for $108 million in cash. Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., has shed other units recently as part of an effort to concentrate on its core business. Oracle, based in Redwood Shores, Calif., said it planned to integrate Digital's data-base products into its own line of software. Digital's Rdb software and Oracle's Oracle 7 software are used by large companies to keep track of high-volume data like customer names and sales information. The Digital unit, with more than $100 million in revenue, is profitable, Oracle said, but revenue has been declining.

title: Hero in Parks Case Is Held
description: A man who captured the person charged with assaulting Rosa Parks, the mother of the civil rights movement, was himself behind bars today, arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on bank robbery charges as he left a television interview.

title: First an Underdog, Then a Favorite, Reneberg Responds to the Pressure
description: Richey Reneberg said he played the best match of his life on Monday night in defeating seventh-seeded Boris Becker under the glare of the Stadium Court in the first round of the United States Open.

title: Johannesburg Journal; Dazzled by Rich South Africa, Migrants Pour In
description: All night, every night, the Mozambican boys grill fatty sausages on little braziers, loitering outside nightclubs among the prostitutes and drug dealers, hoping the police will overlook them and dreading a beating from their employer if their cash comes up short.

title: FLEET BUYS LOAN-SERVICING PORTFOLIO FROM COUNTRYWIDE
description: Fleet Mortgage Group Inc. said yesterday that it had bought the right to service $5.9 billion in mortgages from the Countrywide Funding Corporation, a unit of Countrywide Credit Industries, for an undisclosed price. Fleet Mortgage, a unit of Fleet Financial Group Inc. based in Columbia, S.C., said the purchase brought the total amount of mortgages for which Fleet handles the paperwork to $79.3 billion. In servicing loans, the company collects fees for billing and other services. Countrywide Funding said it decided to sell the package of 55,000 fixed-rate loans because demand had driven up the value of loan servicing.

title: Account Running Dry For Baseball Network
description: Major league players have a $175 million fund from licensing royalties to tide them over during their strike.

title:
COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
A Last-Minute Touchdown Revives Arizona
description: Arizona, picked near the top of most preseason college football polls, dodged a huge bullet tonight when freshman Kevin Schmidtke burst through the middle for a 6-yard touchdown run with 29 seconds to play, giving the Wildcats a 19-14 victory over Georgia Tech tonight in the season opener for both teams.

title: Cuba Denies It Released Convicts as Refugees
description: The Cuban Government today denied American accusations that it had deliberately released criminals from prison so they might join the thousands of Cubans who have fled the island for the United States since last month.

description: A Royal Caribbean ship cut its four-day cruise a day short and returned to port here this morning after more than 400 of the nearly 2,350 people aboard became ill with an unidentified intestinal ailment that caused vomiting, headaches and diarrhea.

description: The newsstand price of The New York Times on weekdays will be raised to 60 cents from 50 cents within the New York metropolitan area, the newspaper announced yesterday.

description: Traditionally, on the day before Labor Day, a group of about 40 friends gathers to sing "Happy Birthday" to JEAN DALRYMPLE, the producer, director, actress and author, who will be 92 on Sunday. They have been at it for almost half a century, said BETSY VON FURSTENBERG, an actress who joined the Dalrymple Birthday Club in 1951.

title: Haiti Agrees to Let 1,000 Refugees Go to U.S.
description: The military-backed government has agreed to allow the departure of more than 1,000 Haitians who have been granted political asylum in the United States, American Embassy officials said today. The first 91 left on Wednesday after being trapped in Haiti for more than a month.

EASEL CORP., Burlington, Mass., named John McDonough president and chief executive.

description: Ira C. Magaziner, the Administration's chief health care planner, yesterday blamed "fear-mongering" and dishonest advertisements by special interest groups for the difficulties encountered by national health insurance legislation on Capitol Hill.

description: Its boulevards swept and repaired, its downtown streets cleared of loiterers, its airport staffed with cheerful young greeters armed with the power to bypass Egypt's notorious customs and immigration bureaucracies, Cairo is ready for the United Nations Conference on Population and Development.

description: Daisy Bates in the Desert A Woman's Life Among the Aborigines By Julia Blackburn Illustrated. 232 pages. Pantheon Books. $22.

title: For British, Move Toward Peace in Northern Ireland Is Still a War of Words
description: The British Government has found itself locked in a war of words, or rather a war over a single word, over how to respond to the Irish Republican Army's cease-fire, which took hold in Northern Ireland early today.

description: To the Editor:

title: Pilots With a Management Attitude
description: Unionized pilots at major airlines have long carried the nickname "flying vice presidents," not only for their high salaries but also for their interest in improving how the company is run. Their determination to gain some control over the company helped lead to the employee buyout of United Airlines this summer, among other deals.

title: Moore's Hand Is Tied In Jets' Season Opener
description: With his left hand wrapped in a cast that goes halfway up his elbow, with fingers protruding but thumb locked in place, what good is Rob Moore on the football field?

description: Everybody in America is tough on crime. Parents, teachers, cops, judges, rich people, poor people, ditch diggers, brain surgeons -- just ask them.

title: Artur Balsam, a Pianist Known For Chamber Work, Dies at 88
description: Artur Balsam, a pianist best known as a chamber player and as an elegant accompanist for violinists and cellists, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 88 and lived in Manhattan.

title: 2 Connecticut Inns: The Guests Pipe Up
description: THE journal lay on the night stand beside the canopied, four-poster bed in a room my wife and I stayed in recently. The journal was opened about midway to a half-written page. This was in the Old Lyme Inn, a white, blue-shuttered, renovated 19th-century home near the seductive shoreline of the Connecticut River, which empties into the nearby Long Island Sound.

description: To the Editor:

title: Still a U.S. Invasion. Still Wrong.
description: The State Department is asking Americans to believe something ridiculous. That is the proposition that an agreement this week by four Lilliputian Caribbean armies to take part in a U.S.-led invasion force signifies regional support for an armed strike against Haiti's military regime.

title: INSIDE
description: Israel and Morocco Seek Ties

title: KMART TO SELL 51% STAKE IN SPORTS AUTHORITY UNIT
description: The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that it had filed plans to sell 51 percent of Sports Authority Inc., its sporting goods unit, in an initial public offering that could raise about $173 million. Kmart filed its plans for the offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission a day after it filed plans to sell a majority stake in another unit, Officemax Inc. Kmart said in its filing that it planned to sell 10.2 million common shares in Sports Authority at a "maximum offering price" of $17 a share. Kmart owns all of Sports Authority and 92 percent of Officemax.

title: Nynex Names Top Executives
description: The Nynex Corporation said yesterday that it had named Alan Senter executive vice president and chief financial officer. Mr. Senter is former senior financial officer of the Xerox Corporation.

title: Miami Beach Journal; The Gold Coast Fights for Its Image
description: Men who walk the tide line on the white sand, nude-bathing beach here say they have come to look for Cuban refugees washing up on American shores.

title: Giants Feeling the Clamp of Salary-Cap Vise
description: As the salary cap takes a stranglehold on the National Football League, choking its victims one by one, Giants players have been unable to escape its crunch. Phil Simms was the first victim and then linebacker Carlton Bailey was approached earlier this week to take a pay cut. The next potential victim who might be asked to cut his paycheck in half is tight end Derek Brown.

title: State Trooper Found Guilty In Fabrication of Evidence
description: A New York State police investigator who once served on an elite unit investigating evidence tampering was found guilty tonight of faking a fingerprint in a 1991 Rockland County carjacking case.

title: Victim's Readiness to Help May Have Cost His Life
description: Theron Montgomery was a big man. He stood at least 6 feet 3 inches and weighed more than 200 pounds. And yesterday people said he was as good as he was big.

title: A Shouter Of the Blues From Chicago
description: Clubs don't usually get a second chance in New York, but Chicago Blues reopened on Wednesday night at 73 Eighth Avenue, at 14th Street, the same location it occupied from October 1991 through the spring of 1992, before the club Zanzibar moved in. As before, it aims to be a transplanted Chicago club, with three sets a night by the same performers who regularly perform on the Midwest's blues circuit. Where New York clubs often hook up a headliner with a house band, Chicago Blues imports entire working groups. The difference should please purists and anyone else who appreciates the relaxed precision of a seasoned band.

title: Police Officer Arrested in Bronx On Charge of Taking Drug Bribes
description: A New York City police officer was arrested in the Bronx yesterday for seeking and accepting bribes from a drug dealer. Senior police officials said he acted alone and was not a part of any corruption ring.

title: Agassi Survives a Challenge
description: Under the spotlights that illuminated the Stadium Court late last night, Andre Agassi cut a formidable figure with his wild hair, brash black socks and tough-guy stubble. But just when he thought he'd pummeled Guy Forget out of contention in straight sets, the white-clothed Frenchman fought back and gave Agassi a witching hour scare.

title: Thomas Chastain, 73, Author Of Best-Selling Mystery Novels
description: Thomas Chastain, a best-selling mystery writer and a former head of the Mystery Writers of America, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 73 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Trying to Cast Light On 3 Troubled Souls
description: They may speak with crabbed Down East accents, but the characters who inhabit "The Keepers," Barbara Lebow's tale of stormy family relationships in a Maine lighthouse in the 1850's, are by no means stereotypically laconic New Englanders. Show them a glimpse of the ocean, which is about all there is to look at in a lighthouse, and they'll spiral into flights of poetic description that seem to turn the stage of the Bouwerie Lane Theater a very ripe shade of purple.

title: Lawyers' Repute Has Faded, but Desire to Be One Hasn't
description: Adam Bonin has read all the horror stories about lawyers -- how hard they work, how little respect they get, how thankless their profession has become. Yet from the first time he saw "L.A. Law," Mr. Bonin says, he knew he wanted to be a lawyer.

title: Crime Bill Bans the Clip Used in Rifle
description: The Chinese assault rifle the police said was used in the killing of a stagehand on Wednesday can no longer be imported into the United States, and its 30-round ammunition clip, which is still sold in this country, would be banned under the crime bill passed last month.

description: * United States Mint, Washington, to the RTC Group, Washington, to handle marketing for its new Civil War battlefield commemorative coins. Billings were estimated at $2.5 million. * CMP Publications, Manhasset, L.I., to Dweck & Campbell, New York, to handle advertising for Home PC magazine. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Fujitsu Challenges Patent
description: Fujitsu Ltd. has asked the Japanese Patent Office to declare invalid the patent that Texas Instruments holds in Japan for the invention of the integrated circuit, a Fujitsu spokeswoman said today.

title: This Candidate Isn't Quite His Daddy's Boy
description: The reason Jeb Bush is the front-runner in the Republican primary for governor of Florida next week may be that he is George Bush's son. But on the campaign trail, he is more the political offspring of a conservative firebrand like Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip, than of his split-the-difference father.

title: A Holy Day And a Parade In Crown Hts.
description: More than a million Caribbean revelers and thousands of Hasidic Jews are expected to mix on the streets of Crown Heights on Monday for two very different kinds of celebrations, and community leaders have their fingers crossed that peace will prevail in this often racially roiled neighborhood.

title: Bush Son Misfires on Hunt For Publicity in Texas Race
description: Today was the first day of the dove hunting season in Texas, and both Gov. Ann W. Richards and George W. Bush, her Republican opponent, were out at the crack of dawn, hunting for birds -- and news coverage.

description: Nancy LaMott

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Candy Maker Merger Wins Agreement
description: In a merger of two old-line family candy manufacturers, the E. J. Brach Corporation agreed today to acquire the Brock Candy Company for $20 a share in cash, or $157 million.

title: Federal Inquiry Is Sought
description: The family of the transit police officer wounded by a New York City police officer in a subway firefight last week has asked for a Federal investigation of the shooting, asserting that the local investigation has been tainted by political concerns.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MCCORMICK & CO., Sparks, Md., has bought the dessert business of Traders Pty. Ltd., Sydney, Australia, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Monitoring Of Wachtler Is a Concern
description: Sol Wachtler's temporary new life sleeping in a Brooklyn halfway house and working at a Long Island real estate company has run into some problems.

title: Village Bohemians From Another Era
description: GREENWICH VILLAGE'S reputation as an outpost of the unconventional is nothing new, as "Beals's Bohemians," a charming show of photographs by Jessie Tarbox Beals at the Museum of the City of New York, demonstrates. Included are more than 50 images of the colorful characters and locations that in the early years of the century gave the area the name "Greenwich Thrillage" and cemented its fame as a haven for nonconformists of all sorts.

title: Team Won't Withdraw
description: British track and field's governing body said yesterday that it would not withdraw its women's team from next week's World Cup, despite pressures to do so after a positive drug test against the 800-meter runner DIANE MODAHL. The world governing body, meanwhile, warned the British that their results could be nullified if Modahl competes.

title: Restaurants
description: In his recently published book, "My Own Country," Dr. Abraham Verghese is told by a traveling salesman how to find a good Indian restaurant in any American city: count the number of Patels in the phone book. If there are more than 10, there will surely be an Indian restaurant and all one need do is call a Patel and ask where it is.

title: Officials Lower Death Total Attributed to Powerful Heroin
description: Authorities yesterday lowered from 14 to 8 the number of deaths in the last week that the police believe are related to highly concentrated heroin being sold on the streets of Manhattan.

title: Unruly Masses
description: Guadelupe was married at age 16. She nodded when the priest said it would be her duty to have all the children God sent. Two children and years of hardship later, she made the most difficult decision of her life. After consulting her doctor but not her priest, she had herself sterilized.

title: Texas Rockabilly, but by Way of the Garage
description: The Reverend Horton Heat, a Dallas trio that performed on Tuesday night at Limelight, plays rockabilly, but not exactly in the tradition of Carl Perkins and Elvis Presley. Its music is rooted in the garage bands that the rockabilly boom spawned, the no-hit rebels who played rock standards with a ragged edge, a new set of lyrics and an exaggerated sense of fun.

title: Yankees Trade A Reliever And Get One
description: Three hours after Paul Gibson received the news from General Manager Gene Michael yesterday that he had been traded from the Yankees to Milwaukee for a player to be determined later, the pitcher was still confused. Gibson's dream of playing in the World Series for the Yankees had been placed in peril by the players' strike and now it was obliterated by the trade.

title: Israel and Morocco Take Fledgling Step Toward Diplomatic Relations
description: Israel and Morocco took the first formal step toward diplomatic relations today, making the kingdom in northern Africa the only Arab country other than Egypt to establish official ties with the Jewish state.

title: Boy Sought in Teen-Ager's Death Is Latest Victim of Chicago Guns
description: The search for an 11-year-old murder suspect ended here today in a dank, graffiti-scarred pedestrian underpass, where the boy was found dead in a pool of blood and mud.

title: Jury Awards $7.1 Million In Sex Case
description: A former secretary at the world's largest law firm who said she had been sexually harassed by a partner there was awarded $7.1 million in punitive damages today, a staggering judgment that is sure to send a chill through legal and business cicrles.

title: Summer's Last Hurrah
description: LABOR DAY pulls in two directions. The unmistakable whiff of cooler weather -- yes, it's out there, even if the thermometer lies and reads 90 -- is a preview of coming attractions, a teaser for full-tilt fall, when leaves die but New York City comes to life. At the same time, shorter days and longer shadows cast a melancholy spell, and put the mind in an elegiac mood.

title: Summer's Last Hurrah: The Final Fling Before the Fall; Inside Story
description: Here are 10 ways to celebrate the Labor Day weekend in the New York metropolitan region. (An introduction appears on page C1.)

title: Twins Pitcher Charged With Drunken Driving
description: Minnesota Twins pitcher PAT MAHOMES was charged yesterday with driving while intoxicated, two other alcohol-related counts and careless driving.

title: PC Outlook Hurts Technology Issues
description: Technology stocks, which had rallied in recent weeks, dropped today amid fears of a slowdown in personal computer sales.

title: Summer's Last Hurrah: The Final Fling Before the Fall; Recircling the Globe
description: Here are 10 ways to celebrate the Labor Day weekend in the New York metropolitan region. (An introduction appears on page C1.)

title: Boy, 13, Is Charged With Murder in Bronx Firebombing
description: A 13-year-old boy has been charged with murder in the firebombing of a Bronx grocery store last week that killed four people, the police said yesterday.

title: STERLING CUTS ITS OFFER FOR KNOWLEDGEWARE
description: Sterling Software Inc. cut the price it will pay for Knowledgeware Inc. by more than 50 percent yesterday, after the struggling software company reported much-larger-than-expected losses. Sterling, which agreed four weeks ago to pay $143 million in stock for Knowledgeware, said it had reduced its stock-swap offer to about $72 million, or $4.88 a share, based on Sterling's recent stock price. Knowledgeware, based in Atlanta, is headed by the former professional football player Fran Tarkenton. The company's shares fell 20.3 cents, to $4.297, in Nasdaq trading of 1.2 million shares. Sterling, based in Dallas, also agreed to invest $7 million in Knowledgeware, which has run out of cash. The merger, which is expected to be completed by mid-November, would create the nation's 11th-largest software company.

title: Treasury Securities Hold Firm
description: Prices of Treasury securities were little changed yesterday after they bounced back from early losses prompted by Government reports suggesting that the economy may not have slowed as much as other data have showed. A weaker dollar discouraged buying.

title: 'Shana Tova' From Arafat
description: Israelis received greetings today for the approaching Jewish New Year from a most unlikely source: Yasir Arafat.

title: Small Crowd at Belmont Opener Sees Drama Down Stretch
description: Belmont Park opened its fall racing season yesterday with lots of sunshine but not lots of people and with few signs that New York racing was healing its financial and political wounds.

title: Swiss Army Knife vs. Chinese Clone
description: The burghers of this hamlet on the slopes of the Swiss Alps have been anxiously watching the progress of a lawsuit in New York, which is expected to determine later this year whether a Swiss Army knife can be cloned in China.

title: Nets Complete Staff by Hiring Wetzel
description: The Nets yesterday hired JOHN WETZEL as an assistant to their new coach, BUTCH BEARD, completing a staff that includes PAUL SILAS and JERRY EAVES. Wetzel comes to the Nets from the Portland Trail Blazers, with whom he spent the last six years as an assistant to the former coach, RICK ADELMAN.

title: Limiting the Plan of a Tax Audit
description: Llona S. Lang of Falls Church, Va., tried to put her bitter, 1988 divorce behind her. But in 1991, she had to dig up personal and financial information in response to a notice of a tax audit from the internal Revenue Service. "I thought I was free and in control of my life," she recalled. "But you aren't free until the I.R.S. says so."

title: New Goodyear Price Rise
description: Citing rising costs of natural rubber, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said this week that it would raise replacement-tire prices 2 percent to 4.5 percent in October, a move that other tire makers are expected to follow.

title: Broncos to Start With a Hole in the Middle
description: Denver Broncos middle linebacker DAVE WYMAN is expected to miss the first two games of the regular season because of torn cartilage in his right knee. Wyman aggravated a two-week-old cartilage injury during Thursday's practice and was scheduled to undergo arthroscopic surgery.

title: A Republican Candidate Shrugs Off Spoiler Tag
description: Pauline Kezer slipped back and forth between roles as she worked the crowd in Bushnell Park, where state office workers flock at lunchtime. One moment she was a Republican candidate for governor, seeking votes in the party's Sept. 13 primary. The next, she was Connecticut's Secretary of the State, encouraging people to register to vote, explaining how to do it, and sending an aide to bring registration forms from her office.

title: The Right Kind of Vaccination Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Colgate May Eliminate Up to 3,000 Positions
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company will reportedly undertake a $100 million restructuring soon that would eliminate up to 3,000 jobs.

title: Chronicle
description: PEDRAG NIKOLIC, the Bosnian grandmaster, was depressed about the future of chess yesterday after being defeated by a computer.

title: ABBOTT IS ADDING NUTRITION CONCERN IN SPAIN
description: Broadening its reach in Europe, Abbott Laboratories said yesterday that it would acquire the nutrition operation of Puleva Union Industrial y Agroganadera S.A. of Spain for about $120 million. Puleva Union Industrial is a dairy and nutrition company. A definitive agreement is expected to be reached later this year, pending completion of Abbott's review of the business and other terms and conditions. The transaction is expected to close by the end of 1994. Abbott, based in Abbott Park, Ill., makes pharmaceuticals, nutritional aids and personal-care products. The company dominates in pediatric and medical nutritional products in the United States, with such offerings as Similac, Isomil and Ensure. Abbott's shares were down 25 cents yesterday, at $29.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: CPI Corp.(CPY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to July 23
description: b-Net income and after a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 2,120,000, or 14 cents a share.(Loss)

title: Players' Union Questions Teams' Roster Moves
description: The baseball strike, which began its fourth week yesterday, has idled 768 players. But the union plans to challenge the status of up to 18 players and force their clubs to pay their salaries for the rest of the season.

title: Rwanda's Bloody Roots
description: The ferocious ethnic violence that tore Rwanda apart this year was no sudden eruption. It began 35 years ago, while the country was preparing, like so many others in Africa, for independence from a European colonial power -- in this case, Belgium, which administered it as part of the United Nations trust territory of Ruanda-Urundi.

title: Deal Openly With Racism in Subway Shooting; Coverage Fuels Hatred
description: To the Editor:

title: Edward T. O'Toole Communications Consultant, 75
description: Edward T. O'Toole, a former bank vice president and a retired financial writer and communications consultant, died on Wednesday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 75.

title: Franklin Supply Co. reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included gain of $ 3,387,000 on debt refinancing.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: OFFICER'S PARTNER TELLS OF SHOOTING

title: Deaf Boy, 4, Loses Hand in Blast Of Firecracker in Queens Home
description: The left hand of a 4-year-old deaf boy, who relies on sign language to communicate, had to be amputated yesterday after it was mangled when a large firecracker that the boy was playing with exploded, the police said.

title: Buying College Students a Place to Live
description: Two children in the same college at the same time meant student housing costs of $1,000 a month for Bob Farshler, a petroleum engineer in Corpus Christi, Tex., and his wife, Inga, a librarian

title: A Gear, a Drill, a Fan, a Cuban Raft
description: Never has make-do ingenuity been more evident than in the design of the hundreds of Cuban rafts that have put to sea in the recent exodus.

title: Hush Falls Over Open as Medvedev Loses
description: While the 11th-seeded Jim Courier was at least fighting in vain to stave off elimination on the Stadium Court yesterday at the United States Open, an even higher-seeded player on the men's side, No. 8 Andrei Medvedev, was going down rather quietly on the Grandstand Court.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GE SILICONES, Waterford, N.Y., a division of GE Plastics, which is a subsidiary of General Electric Co., said it had acquired a majority interest in Tosil, its silicones joint venture with Toshiba Corp., Tokyo, the industrial and consumer electronics concern. Terms were not disclosed. OREGON STEEL MILLS INC., Portland, Ore., said it would build a $180 million combination mill and close an older plant in Fontana, Calif., resulting in the loss of about 100 jobs and a charge of about $14 million.

title: Anglers Ignore Hudson Warnings; Most Either Don't Know of Cancer Concern or Don't Care
description: Tommy Jackson has heard all the warnings against eating the striped bass, white perch and eel that he pulls from the PCB-polluted waters of the Hudson River.

title: Chronicle
description: YASIR ARAFAT, the Palestinian leader, and YITZHAK RABIN, the Prime Minister of Israel, have won the Prince of Asturias Peace Prize, awarded by Spain, The Associated Press reported.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Wednesday about "Dancing Under the Stars," a tap-dancing show on Monday at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, misidentified a lead dancer because of an incorrect listing in the program. He was Herbin van Cayseele, not Van Porter.

title: Rodman & Renshaw Capital Group Inc.(RR,N) reports earnings for Year to June 24
description: b-Included $ 17 million in restructuring charges, which included certain expenses related to the acquisition of a majority ownership in the company by Abaco Casa de Bolsa.c-Net income(Loss)

title: Sampras Puts In a Day's Work in 1 Hour 45 Minutes
description: None of this late-night baloney for Pete Sampras. He made short work of Daniel Vacek, needing 1 hour 45 minutes to complete a routine second-round match that got him into the locker room before 10 P.M. and on the way back to his Long Island retreat not much later.

title: Man Who Was Paid To Quit Swarthmore Won't Be Returning
description: The student who was paid by Swarthmore College to attend Boston University after a classmate accused him of harassment has refused Swarthmore's offer of readmission.

title: Cuban-Americans Caution on Talks
description: Members of a conservative Cuban-American group warned congressmen and a Clinton Administration envoy Thursday night that Cuban areas of Miami would "explode" if talks with Fidel Castro's Government produced concessions to Havana.

title: Perry Drug Stores Inc.(PDS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge on early retirement of debt of $ 1,295,000, or 11 cents a share, in both the quarter and 9 months.c-Net incomed-Net lossLatest quarter and 9 months' income from continuing operations of $ 221,000, or 2 cents a share, and $ 4,890,000, or 41 cents a share, respectively, included a charge on proposed settlement of litigation of $ 1.1 million, or 9 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 600,000, or 5 cents a share, in the 9 months.(Loss)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League BOSTON RED SOX -- Recalled Gar Finnvold, pitcher, from Pawtucket of the International League.

title: DROP IN NEW JOBS SIGNALS A SLOWING FOR THE ECONOMY
description: Employment figures released today provided the clearest evidence to date that the economy has slowed from last year's unsustainable pace, but that it retains enough strength to avoid braking too severely.

title: A Skillful Feat Saves Russia Space Station
description: With the future of Russia's space program resting in his hands, the commander of the orbiting Russian space station Mir manually docked with a cargo ship carrying supplies needed to keep the station operating.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a pop music review yesterday about the Horde tour misidentified the site of the Lollapalooza Festival last month. It was at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island, not at Jones Beach.

title: Fast-Track the Metrocard
description: It seemed like such a great idea: Do away with bulky tokens and replace them with a plastic card that passengers could merely swipe through an electronic slot to enter the subway. For the first buyers of the new Metrocards, though, they also brought frustration. Zipping through the turnstile after buying the card, some unwary commuters who hadn't read the fine print on the posters imagined token-free futures. On the ride back, they often found out differently.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Eagle Helps Albus Secure Seniors Lead Jim Albus made a 12-foot eagle putt on the final hole yesterday for a six-under-par 66 and a one-stroke lead over Tony Jacklin in the G.T.E. Northwest Classic in Kenmore, Wash. Albus, a former club pro on Long Island and on Staten Island, is a two-time winner this season on the Senior PGA Tour. He set up the eagle with a 330-yard drive and a 7-iron approach on the downhill 495-yard hole. Arnold Palmer also had an eagle on the final hole yesterday, sinking a 50-foot putt, to finish his round of 70. (AP)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Cocoa Hits a 2-Month Low; Natural Gas Prices Decline
description: Cocoa prices fell to a two-month low yesterday as traders grew confident that steady rain in the Ivory Coast would benefit this year's crop.

title: Lenders More Forgiving Of Poor Credit Records
description: PEOPLE with smudged credit records are finding it easier to buy a home these days as hard-pressed lenders seeking customers become more forgiving of applicants with a history of late payments, delinquencies and even bankruptcies. Mortgages are usually graded "A" through "D" for risk. An "A" mortgage conforms to the standards set by the major mortgage buyers in the secondary market, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-4 MORE VIOLENCE IN ULSTER A killing in Belfast was a reminder that despite the Irish Republican Army's declaration of a cease-fire, peace in Northern Ireland remains a distant possibility. 1 U.S. TO INCREASE IRISH AID President Clinton met with Ireland's Deputy Prime Minister and said he would reward the moves for peace by increasing aid to both Ireland and Northern Ireland. 3 PROGRESS IN CUBA TALKS American and Cuban officials continued their talks, and Administration officials said they had offered to greatly increase the number of Cubans who would be granted legal entry to the United States. 4 WARNING FROM CUBAN EXILES A conservative group among Cuban exiles in the United States warned of an angry reaction if the talks with Cuba at the United Nations were to produce concessions. 4 Cuban refugee rafts are models of make-do ingenuity. 4 CHINESE SNUB TO SOUTH KOREA China withdrew from a body that oversees the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea, and the move was seen as an effort to cut South Korea out of the discussion of the future of the Korean Peninsula. 3 ETHNIC CLEANSING IN BOSNIA Bosnian Serbs have opened a new intensive campaign of ethnic cleansing against Muslims, and more than 500 people were expelled from their homes in a single instance Thursday night in northern Bosnia. 2 RUSSIAN MANEUVER IN SPACE With the space program resting in his hands and fuel for only one more try, the commander of the orbiting Russian space station Mir succeeded in docking with supplies that were desperately needed. 2 SWISS KNIFE VS. title: Transit Officer Says Policeman Fired in Anger
description: The partner of the undercover transit officer wounded in a subway shootout last week has told investigators that the off-duty New York City police officer who mistakenly fired on the undercover officer "was shooting with a vengeance," and appeared intent on killing him.

title: New Jersey Boy, 13, Is Charged With Killing 11-Year-Old Friend
description: A polite, helpful 11-year-old who everybody called Jake was fatally shot in his bedroom in this small rural town on Thursday, and a 13-year-old friend was charged hours later with killing him.

title: N.H.L. Arranges Treatment for Probert
description: Chicago Blackhawks right wing BOB PROBERT was placed on indefinite inactive status yesterday by National Hockey League Commissioner GARY BETTMAN for league-supervised treatment for substance abuse.

title: China, Backing North Korea, Quits Armistice Commission
description: The Chinese Government stunned South Korea today by announcing that it was withdrawing its delegate from the four-decade-old military commission that oversees the armistice between North and South Korea.

Deal Openly With Racism in Subway Shooting
description: To the Editor:

title: VENTRITEX STOCK FALLS FOLLOWING EARNINGS REPORT
description: Ventritex Inc. shares tumbled yesterday after the company told analysts that its first-quarter earnings would fall short of expectations. A Department of Health and Human Services investigation of hospital reimbursement for medical procedures has slowed sales and caused the company to lose market share, said Frank Fischer, Ventritex chief executive. The news prompted several analysts to slash estimates for the company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., a maker of implantable defibrillators, devices to correct an erratic heartbeat. Ventritex's shares slipped $4.50, or 19 percent, to $18.50, in Nasdaq trading yesterday.

title: Labor Day Approaches For Harvard
description: WHEN this year's Labor Day Parade was called off, Ted Jacobsen, the secretary of the New York City Labor Council, said one major reason was that by and large labor had won.

title: Virtual Mayhem and Real Profits
description: American McGee chases his colleague Shawn Green through the office, leaping over acid pits and dodging radioactive debris before cornering him in a cul-de-sac. "Here, have some of THIS!" Mr. McGee says with a cackle, as he empties his plasma rifle into Mr. Green's neck.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a fatal shooting on Wednesday in Rockefeller Center misspelled the name of a co-host of the "Today" program. He is Bryant Gumbel.

title: Evidence of Mick Jagger's Influence
description: As the 51-year-old Mick Jagger romps across stadium stages this summer, clones nearly half his age are strutting the same strut in clubs. Mr. Jagger's influence hangs heavily over contemporary British rock. The singers in many popular new bands, including Primal Scream, the Charlatans, Oasis and Verve, have all incorporated elements of Mr. Jagger's onstage moves and singing style into their persona.

title: Big Board Stocks Slip, But Nasdaq Edges Up
description: The stock market, facing an unchanged unemployment rate in August, closed mixed yesterday, as traders began to shift their worries from an overheating economy to declining corporate profits in a sluggish economy.

title: Simpson Defense Attacks Theory of Single Assailant
description: Offering an early outline of their defense, lawyers for O. J. Simpson argue in newly released court papers that it is unlikely that one person acting alone could have killed his former wife and her friend.

title: Observer; Probably an Oversight
description: I see that somebody else has drawn up a list of New York's living human treasures and that they are to be honored soon at one of the better hotels.

title: A Slaying Shows Ulster Peace Is Still Elusive
description: It was a killing like hundreds of others over the last 25 years in Northern Ireland: a group of gunmen approached a man repairing a car on a Belfast Street, shot him dead and fled. The victim was Roman Catholic; the killers were members of the Ulster Freedom Fighters, a Protestant paramilitary group.

title: Ulster Truce Could Bring A 'Dividend'
description: Interrupting his vacation to meet with Ireland's Deputy Prime Minister, President Clinton signaled today that he intends to reward the turn toward peace in Northern Ireland with a substantial increase in United States aid.

title: High Officer At Met Life Gets New Job
description: Robert J. Crimmins, who was the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's executive in charge of personal insurance when state regulators found that many Met Life agents were guilty of improper sales activities, has been reassigned.

title: Edison Brothers Stores Inc.(EBS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Brazil Winces at Film on Its Hero
description: "The Burning Season," an American made-for-television film about a Brazilian Amazon hero, was screened here on Thursday night for Brazil's film glitterati in the Beaux-Arts splendor of the Municipal Theater. The response was less than enthusiastic.

title: Leslie Fay's Law Firm Didn't Act Improperly
description: To the Editor:

title: Serbs, Too, Suffered 'Ethnic Cleansing'
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Bonds Sag on Hint Of Inflation
description: Prices of Treasury securities slumped yesterday in a shortened trading session after a quick, early surge, as traders managed to find hints of inflationary pressures even though August's employment report was soft.

title: No Cause Is Found In Family's Deaths
description: The mystery surrounding the death of a woman and her three children in a Manhattan housing project deepened after autopsies yesterday proved inconclusive.

title: Corrections
description: A chart with an article in Business Day on Wednesday about Wall Street firms entering the corporate loan business misidentified a source for its data. The source was the Loan Pricing Corporation, not the Loan Processing Corporation.

title: STOCK OF SUNSHINE-JR. STORES INCREASES BY 23%
description: The stock of Sunshine-Jr. Stores Inc. closed up 23 percent yesterday after the company, a convenience-store chain, said it was in talks with prospective buyers. Sunshine-Jr. stock closed up $2.25, at $12. The discussions are preliminary, the company said, and may not result in any offer or sale. The retailer, based in Panama City, Fla., said any sale would be subject to a "fairness opinion" from the board's financial advisers and the approval of the company's board and major shareholders.

title: Disabled Have Right To Live Anywhere
description: To the Editor:

title:
FOOTBALL;
Seifert's Personal Problem: Good Simply Won't Cut It
description: George Seifert's credentials as the San Francisco 49ers' coach are as glittering as the Vince Lombardi Trophy. He won a Super Bowl in his first year after replacing Bill Walsh. He won 50 games faster than any coach in the history of the National Football League. His overall winning percentage is .714.

title: John Wade, 83, Torts Authority And Dean of Law at Vanderbilt
description: John W. Wade, an authority on tort law who was dean of Vanderbilt University's law school from 1952 to 1971, died on Aug. 24 at his home in Nashville, Tenn. He was 83.

title: Q & A
description: Figuring REIT Earnings Q. When discussing the results of REIT's, analysts often concentrate on "funds from operations" rather than earnings as defined by standard accounting principles. How do they differ?ROSS CASLEY, Palo Alto, Calif. A. Although REIT's, or real estate investment trusts, are traded on stock exchanges, they are not stocks of companies. They are investment pools, similar to mutual funds, that put their money into real estate or mortgage loans.

title: Citing Safety, U.S. Bans Airlines of 9 Nations
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has barred airlines from nine nations from flying to the United States because of poor safety procedures.

title: Fire in a Homeless Warren Disrupts Subway Line
description: A suspicious fire in a subway cable room in Chelsea, where a homeless person had broken in and set up Stygian housekeeping, forced authorities to shut down power on the Eighth Avenue line and reroute hundreds of trains for most of the morning yesterday in a chain reaction that affected more than 250,000 riders on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Aug. 20, about uncovered short sales on the New York and American Stock Exchanges for the month ended Aug. 15, included an erroneous figure provided by the American Stock Exchange for its total short interest in the period. It was 107.22 million shares, not 107.27 million shares.

title: 2 Brothers Held in Slaying of a Murder Suspect, 11
description: Two teen-age brothers, bright but troubled, according to their grade school basketball coach, were charged today in the slaying of an 11-year-old boy who himself was being sought by the police as a suspected killer.

title: Serb Gang Expels 566 Muslims From Their Homes in Bosnia
description: In the largest single instance of "ethnic cleansing" in months, a gang of nationalist Serbs drove 566 Muslims from their homes Thursday night in Bijeljina, in northern Bosnia, United Nations officials here said today.

title: Selig's Threat: Settle Soon, or Wait Till Next Year
description: If striking players and owners do not reach an agreement by Friday, the owners are prepared to cancel the rest of the baseball season and the post-season, Bud Selig told Donald Fehr yesterday as the strike completed its 22d day.

title: OPTIMISTIC OUTLOOK IN COMPUTER INDUSTRY LIFTS STOCK
description: The shares of the Amdahl Corporation reached a 52-week high yesterday on an optimistic outlook for the mainframe computer industry. Shares of the No. 2 mainframe maker rose 87.5 cents, to $10.125, on Nasdaq volume of 1.6 million shares. Amdahl shares, which traded as low as $5.25 in early July, began climbing after second-quarter earnings reflected lower costs and healthy demand for mainframe companies like the International Business Machines Corporation, Tandem Computers Inc. and Amdahl. The stock has jumped 42 percent since Aug. 23. Amdahl is expected to see increased sales because I.B.M. has said it has sold out of its mainframe products through the end of the year, sending more customers to Amdahl for I.B.M. clones, analysts said.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Labor Day will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK GOVERNMENT OFFICES Closed. POST OFFICE Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. BANKS Closed. PARKING Sunday rules in effect. SANITATION No pickups, street cleanings or recycling. SCHOOLS Closed. FINANCIAL MARKETS Closed. TRANSPORTATION Buses and subways on Sunday schedule. Long Island Rail Road on holiday schedule. Metro-North on holiday schedule. NEW JERSEY GOVERNMENT OFFICES Closed. POST OFFICES Express mail and special delivery only. BANKS Closed. SCHOOLS Closed. TRANSPORTATION New Jersey Transit on Sunday schedule. CONNECTICUT GOVERNMENT OFFICES Closed. POST OFFICES Closed. BANKS Closed. SCHOOLS Closed. TRANSPORTATION Holiday schedule Traffic Alert MONDAY WEST INDIAN PARADE The following streets will be closed from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M.: Buffalo Avenue between New York Avenue and Eastern Boulevard; Rochester Avenue between New York Avenue and Eastern Boulevard; Eastern Boulevard between Utica Avenue and Grand Army Plaza. The parade begins at 11 A.M.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: O'Sullivan Aiming at World Record
description: Tonight in Paris, Sonia O'Sullivan of Ireland is poised to top her already sensational summer and affirm her new status as the world's leading female distance runner. In the process, she could set a world record.

title: San Francisco Abandons the Deion Derby
description: The San Francisco 49ers pulled out of the bidding for the free agent cornerback DEION SANDERS yesterday, saying that salary cap constraints made it impossible to match or beat competing offers.

title: Dorothy B. Phillips, a Director Of Special Olympics, Dies at 83
description: Dorothy Buehring Phillips, a lifelong champion of the disabled and the founder and first State Director of the New York Special Olympics, died on Wednesday at Fannie Allen Hospital in Colchester, Vt. She was 83 and lived in Albany until three months ago, when she moved to Williston, Vt.

title: Bailey's Motivation Will Be on Display
description: When Carlton Bailey was benched this week in favor of linebacker Corey Widmer, he could have lashed out and made the situation worse. But he didn't and he hasn't since. He has handled the affair with dignity.

title: 'Flexible' Plant for Fast-Changing Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation's assembly plant here, which has undergone a $300 million retooling in the last five months, exhibits the route Chrysler has traveled in pursuit of Japanese quality and productivity -- and the distance it still must travel to close the gap.

title: In the Race to Raise Funds, Pataki Pulls Ahead of Cuomo
description: In a month when his campaign was often on the defensive because of questions about his personal finances, Senator George E. Pataki, the leading Republican candidate for Governor, still managed to raise more money than Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in some editions of Business Day yesterday, about a settlement of Securities and Exchange Commission charges by a trader at Shearson Lehman Advisers and her husband, misstated the couple's response to the charges. The couple, Donna and Philip Tumminia, neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing.

title: School Panel's District Plan Ignites Debate
description: A proposal to redraw the boundaries of New York City school districts for the first time in more than two decades would increase the percentages of minority and immigrant students in several districts in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx, while making other districts whiter.

title: Courier Comeback Turns Into a Quick Ticket Back Home
description: More familiar faces and story lines, rapidly diminishing items, disappeared yesterday from the United States Open. Chief among them were Jim Courier's comeback from an eyeblink of a self-imposed exile and Conchita Martinez's chance to chase Arantxa Sanchez-Vicario to a semifinal confrontation for the championship of Spain.

title: Schumann in the Afternoon, at Federal Hall
description: Concertgoers at loose ends during the lull between summer festivals and the start of the regular concert season could do worse than explore some of the byways of New York's musical life. There is, for example, a series of free concerts at Federal Hall on Wednesday afternoons, presented by the American Landmark Festivals. This week the recitalist was Zaidee Parkinson, who devoted herself fully to works of Schumann.

title: With Brazil's New Prosperity Come Arby's and Pizza Hut
description: On Avenida Paulista, a canyon of corporate headquarters in South America's largest city, office workers looking for lunch can choose among four McDonald's, a Pizza Hut, an Arby's and a KFC.

title: Ares-Sereno reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 9,620,000 and $ 9,619,000 in the quarter and 6 months, respectively.c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,390,000 in the quarter and $ 2,932,000 in the 6 months.

title: HUD to End Inquiries Into Protests of Its Proposals
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development said today that it would no longer investigate people who fought its proposals with letter-writing, pamphleteering or other forms of peaceful protest.

title: Shoney's Inc.(SHN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 7
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from early retirement of debt of $ 1,038,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $

description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: The theft of a jug filled with change from a bagel shop in New Jersey caught the attention of PRESCOTT ROBERT TISCH and brought in $10,000 for a little boy with brain cancer.

title: Knicks Talk With Ron Harper
description: The Knicks have held several discussions with Ron Harper, the free-agent guard who played last season with the Los Angeles Clippers, but do not appear close to a deal and might wait until after Sept. 12 before making a move to sign him.

title: Bids Climb In Western Union Sale
description: The latest round of a bidding war for Western Union Financial Services, the world's largest money-transfer business, ended yesterday with First Financial Management turning in the highest offer, valued at $1.07 billion.

title:
CAVEAT EMPTOR;
An S.E.C. Panel Is Taking a Hard Look at Stockbrokers
description: The job of a stockbroker is to match up each client with the investments that best meet his or her needs at the best possible price, right? Well, yes. But brokers often face conflicts that pit their own compensation and well-being against the needs of their clients.

title: INSIDE
description: Bosnian Muslims Expelled

title: Supply Craft Docks With Mir Space Station After 2 Failures
description: With the future of Russia's manned space program resting in his nervous hands, the commander of the orbiting space station Mir docked today with a cargo ship delivering urgently needed food and supplies.

title: Letters Show Thief Knew Value Of the Quedlinburg Treasures
description: An American Army lieutenant's letters home from Germany in 1945 describing his involvement in one of the greatest art thefts of the century go far to answer questions raised in the legal battle and subsequent negotiations that led to the return of the so-called Quedlinburg treasure to Germany in 1992.

title: Dollar Loses Early Gains After a Bond Rally Fizzles
description: The dollar fell against most other leading currencies yesterday, giving up early gains after a rally in the Treasury market evaporated.

title: Executive Changes
description: EQUICREDIT CORP. Jacksonville, Fla., named Allen F. Tuthill senior vice president for wholesale originations. GENERAL ELECTRIC CO. Fairfield, Conn., named Mei-Wei Cheng president and chief executive of GE China. The executive will be based in Beijing.

title: Seminoles Are Eager To Play Opener
description: An off season of turmoil ends on Saturday afternoon for Florida State's defending national champions. For Coach Bobby Bowden, it cannot come be soon enough.

title: Divided Justice
description: New York is the only American city under the jurisdiction of two Federal prosecutors. This represents a threat to justice.

title: Ex-Mayor Of Capital Runs Hard
description: Once dubbed Mayor for Life, then disgraced and jailed, Marion S. Barry Jr. has been finding eager listeners for his campaign message of rehabilitation and redemption.

title: One Stop at a Time, Sharpton Broadens Political Following
description: Campaigning as a revivalist as much as a politician, the Rev. Al Sharpton is using another aggressive primary challenge of the Democratic establishment to capitalize on black voters' shock last year at David N. Dinkins's loss of City Hall to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Deadly Frat Pranks
description: In the past 10 years, 23 people have died as a result of hazing or other fraternity-related activities. Many more are brutalized each year, and there is little sign that such practices are on the wane. Indeed, as another wave of first-year students sets out for campuses in the next few weeks, one thing is certain. By the time the snow flies, many of those who pledge Greek-letter fraternities and sororities will be subjected to experiences that are at best unpleasant and at worst life-threatening.

title: Purepac Inc. reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included gain of $ 4,149,000, or 33 cents a share, for cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes.c-Included gain of $ 936,000 for utilization of available loss carryforwards for accounting for income taxes.

title: Isles' Volek, Beset by Bad Back, Retires
description: Islanders right wing DAVID VOLEK, who scored the winning goal in overtime of Game 7 of the 1993 Patrick Division final against the Pittsburgh Penguins, retired yesterday.

title:
INVESTING;
New York State Gives Protection to I.R.A.'s
description: A RETIRED obstetrician recently considered moving from New York to Florida because the bulk of his life savings, which were in an individual retirement account, were threatened by a malpractice suit filed by a former patient. Florida protects I.R.A.'s in bankruptcy. New York did not.

title: Beliefs
description: Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, arrives Monday evening, and with it begins a 10-day period leading up to Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, in which a rabbi may be called upon to preach three, four or even more sermons.

title: Jets Look to Opener With Bills As a Historical Turning Point
description: Just one big victory. That's all the Jets want as they open their first season under Coach Pete Carroll on Sunday. And why not win on opening day against Buffalo at the Bills' home?

title: New Offerings Reach the Market
description: Elizabeth Bramwell ran the Gabelli Growth Fund from its inception until earlier this year, when she set up her own shop. The first of her new funds, the Bramwell Growth Fund, looks for companies with new products or markets. It invests mainly in common stock and convertible securities.

title: Notes on Bipartisanship
description: In the era of gridlock, there is a new Labor Day vacation ritual. Whenever members of Congress go home to face the public, they raise a mighty, nostalgic hymn to the vanished era of bipartisanship. It goes something like this. Back in the halcyon days of Ike and L.B.J., each side fought its corner hard and fair. Then, when the hour was late and the need was great, a critical centrist majority would come together to vote for the "good of the country."

title: Bridge; U.S. junior teams will face distractions next year: from Europe, the opponents, and Bali, the site.
description: In the past 45 years world championships have been played in some beautiful and exciting spots: New Orleans, Rio de Janeiro, Paris, Monte Carlo, Venice, and a tiny resort in the Italian Alps called St. Vincent, for example. But they will all be surpassed next year, when the World Junior Team Championship is held on the exotic island of Bali, Indonesia.

title: Deal Openly With Racism in Subway Shooting; Police Dept. Spin
description: To the Editor:

title: Haitians Bury Slain Priest As a Hero
description: An assassinated Haitian priest was buried as a hero today, the most visible victim so far in what his mourners call the systematic killing and oppression of the Haitian people.

title: K. C. Jones Returns as Aide With Pistons
description: K. C. JONES, who has been a part of 12 National Basketball Association championship teams as a player and coach, has joined the Detroit Pistons as an assistant coach.

title: Verkhoyansk Journal; A Siberian Icebox That Holds a Thousand People
description: Summer can be stressful in the coldest place on earth: It becomes impossible to walk across the Yana River, which is frozen solid nine months a year. Houses sometimes snap in two when the ice beneath them weakens and shifts a little. Vodka prices soar.

title: Plan to Cut Costs of Concrete Results in Higher Costs Instead
description: Eight years ago, New York City officials had a bright idea that they thought would save money and weaken the Mafia's power at the same time.

title: Suspect in Slaying At Studio Arraigned
description: The suspect in the shooting of a part-time stagehand on the sidewalk outside an NBC television studio in mid-Manhattan was arraigned early yesterday on a second-degree murder charge.

title: School Uniforms Growing in Favor in California
description: Surrounded by a sea of white shirts and navy blue shorts in a local department store's new section devoted to school uniforms, 7-year-old Sean Smith dangled his feet from a shopping cart and proudly puffed out his chest to display the Tasmanian devil emblazoned on his favorite T-shirt.

title: Sports of The Times; Lewis Says This Is All For McCall
description: WHILE Oliver McCall may be someone to take seriously, his nickname, the Atomic Bull, isn't, said Lennox Lewis. "Everyone who steps into the ring can do damage if you're not careful," said Lewis, "but that nickname doesn't mean anything to me except he's got a bulldog style and I don't have to look for him. He'll come to me. And that will be just lovely."

title: No Conflict in Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: Acklands Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company said it completed the acquisition of Autotec Inc. on August 29. It said it is actively pursuing acquisition opportunities in the U.S.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Police Find $125,000 in Duffel Bag in Cab
description: Two plainclothes police officers discovered at least $125,000 in a duffel bag in the back of a livery cab in Queens yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: U.S. and Cuba Make Progress on Refugees
description: United States and Cuban negotiators made progress today in talks focusing on a proposal by the Clinton Administration to vastly increase the number of Cubans who would be granted entry through legal means if Havana agreed to halt the chaotic flow of boat people, American officials said.

title: No Headline
description: He was shooting with a vengeance. It wasn't like he was shooting to run for cover, like he was shooting for someone to go down. He wanted to kill that person he was shooting. -- OFFICER DAVID THOMPSON of the Transit Police, whose partner was shot by another officer. [ 1:5. ]

title: Mid-Chicago Course
description: Golf may be the quintessential suburban experience, but not in Chicago. This summer, the country's first center-city golf course opened in a former rail yard along Chicago's Lake Michigan shore, a short stroll from fashionable Michigan Avenue. Golfers playing the nine-hole, par-27 course at Illinois Center Golf can gaze up from the fairway at Sears Tower, the John Hancock Building and, just across the street, the 80-story Amoco Building. Less pleasant reminders of urban life are traffic sounds. But the lush fairways -- and hidden sand traps -- are pure country club. The course, at 221 North Columbus Drive, charges $22 to play nine holes. Call (312) 616-1234. TERRY TRUCCO

title: Vivian C. Chen, Patrick J. Biggins
description: Vivian Cecily Chen, the daughter of Lina and Raymond T. Chen of Plainview, L.I., was married yesterday to Patrick Joseph Biggins, a son of Maureen and John J. Biggins of Walnut Creek, Calif. Rabbi Michael Rosen performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Garden City Hotel in Garden City, L.I.

title: Not Exactly the Song of Norway
description: MORTEN GUNNAR LARSEN'S parents weren't exactly scandalized when he suggested, while still a student at the Norwegian Music Academy in Oslo, that he might prefer playing the music of Jelly Roll Morton and Scott Joplin to that of Grieg and Sibelius. Neither were they entirely supportive.

title: Fear and Pain in Haiti
description: The ordeal of a Haitian family whose members suffered brutal attacks is an example of human rights abuses in Haiti. Family members are in hiding, and with only a small number of those approved for emigration making their way out, they say their hopes of escape are fading.

title: Stacy A. Rotta, Mark E. Holmen
description: Stacy Ann Rotta, a daughter of Rita P. Rotta of Birmingham, Mich., and Lawrence E. Rotta of Mount Clemens, Mich., was married yesterday to Mark Eric Holmen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Robert Holmen of Vero Beach, Fla. The Rev. Charles Kavanagh, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Chapel of the Snows in Stratton Mountain, Vt.

title:
Profile;
Reaping the Rewards of Stick-to-itiveness
description: THEY don't look like the building blocks of a multimillion-dollar industry: small sticker renderings of delicate flowers, shiny aliens, glow-in-the-dark angels, Edwardian Santas, fuzzy bears and the like. Costing less than a penny each to make, they sell for little more than pocket change.

title:
BEHIND THW WHEEL/1995 Volkswagen Passat GLX;
A Heavy Hauler With Smart Moves
description: FOREVER etched in my memory is the test I took for my first driver's license in my parents' 1963 Chevrolet Bel Air station wagon. As if it were yesterday, I remember cranking the steering wheel with all my then-90-pound might to parallel-park the garnet-colored, two-ton behemoth and make the required three-point turn.

title: U.S. to Charter Boats and Jets if Hurricane Nears Guantanamo
description: The threat of seasonal hurricanes in the Caribbean has prompted American military planners to draft an emergency plan to shelter or evacuate tens of thousands of Cuban and Haitian refugees living in tent cities at the Guantanamo Bay naval base.

title: THE NATION: Taking Sausage; The Art of Reprocessing the Democratic Process
description: ALREADY, some pundits and politicians are weaving a tidy narrative around the collapse of health care reform. The Clinton Administration overreached, they say. After a long and vigorous debate about the Clinton plan, people gradually turned away from the idea of a comprehensive overhaul and Congress responded to their will. The Framers, in other words, would be pleased; the system worked.

title: School District That Still Isn't Ready for School
description: Brooklyn's largest school district, in such disarray three-and-a-half years ago that Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez seized control of it, is once again being ripped apart by school board politics.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 Amid the crush of U.S. Open ephemera, someone has to take care of the basics -- the ball, the racquet, the score. NEW YORKERS & CO. 4 In the brutal money-management world, Laura Sloate is as tough as they come. No big deal, but she's also blind.

title: It May be the Name Game, but They're All Business
description: IN the days of Bazooka Joe and Ivory Soap, advertising agencies did it all, giving life to products through dependable names, catchy packaging and unforgettable slogans.

title: William Hurt Resurfaces, as a Character Actor
description: JUST BEFORE "BODY HEAT" opened in 1981, the film's star William Hurt, then 31 years old, described himself to Judy Klemesrud of The New York Times as a character actor trapped "in a leading man's body."

title: U.N. Is Facing Angry Debate On Population
description: Already mired in an angry debate over abortion and women's rights, the United Nations Conference on Population and Development will confront other equally volatile issues when it opens here Monday.

title: Where Have You Gone, Robert Frank?
description: HE BATTERED FURNISHINGS IN THE LOFT where the artists Robert Frank and June Leaf have lived since 1971 offer few of the comforts and joys taken for granted by most Americans. A former S.R.O. hotel off the Bowery in lower Manhattan, its front criss-crossed with graffiti and sheets of plywood, the place feels as if it still might belong to vagrants. Leaf's clothes hang from a portable dress trolley in the hallway. A plastic shower stall is wedged next to the tiny stove in the kitchen. The exposed brick walls and rough, unvarnished wood on the three floors would need weeks of scrubbing to pass muster as a yuppie dwelling.

title: The Lincoln Brigade
description: To the Editor:

title: Winning Over Brokers to Home Sales by Computer
description: ENTREPRENEURS who hope to revolutionize home buying by giving consumers a chance to shop via computer have tripped over a major hurdle -- the brokers. But some are apparently recovering their footing. They are beginning to enter into relationships with residential brokers rather than compete with them, which could lead to more computerization in home shopping. Broker collaboration would mean larger, and more frequently, updated computerized listings of homes for sale.

title: When Quiet Is Pervasive In Schools
description: Dark brown braids hanging from her bowed head, 7-year-old Tiffanie Daniels closed her eyes and said a silent prayer: "Please, God, give me a happy year and a long, good life."

title: THE NEWEST MOYNIHAN
description: If being a United States Senator involved only a grasp of minutiae, Daniel Patrick Moynihan would indeed be the best man for the job ("The Newest Moynihan," by Todd S. Purdum, Aug. 7). But voters deserve more than a professorial "Jeopardy!" contestant.

title:
DINING OUT;
Vibrant, Freewheeling Style of Cooking
description: "NEVER eat more than you can lift," Miss Piggy once said. But that advice appears to be ignored on a regular basis at Biaggio's, a friendly storefront in North Haledon, not far from Wayne.

title: Andrea Mohin, Jack Robertiello
description: Andrea Lee Mohin, a photographer at The New York Times, and Jack Robertiello, a food and travel writer, are to be married today at the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture. Jean S. Kotkin, a former president of the Ethical Culture Union, is to officiate.

Fone of Sherborn, Mass. The Rev. Beulah Koulouris, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Church in Osterville, Mass.

description: To the Editor:
